bestBHT.bht: In the unfolding events of that night, there is a climactic moment when the cock crows twice. This signifies the passing of time and symbolizes the impending denial to come. The denial will not only happen on that day but specifically during this night, before it is even over. The emphasis on the second crowing of the cock brings clarity to the timeline, noting that the denial will occur long before the break of dawn.

Henry Alford: Notice the climax: this day, but not only this—in this night, the part of it now present.
nor only so, but before the cock crow twice, i.e., long before the night is over.
Marvin Vincent: Cock crow. See on Matthew 26:34. Mark alone adds twice. Deny [απαρνηση] . The compound verb signifies utterly deny.
Philip Schaff: Before the cock crow twice. Before the usual time of the second cock-crowing, about three o’clock in the morning.
This night. The prediction becomes more specific.
Archibald T. Robertson: One crowing is always the signal for more.
The Fayum papyrus agrees with Mark in having δις.
The cock-crowing marks the third watch of the night.
John Gill: Verily I say unto thee, as confident as thou art of standing by me, and abiding with me.
Before the cock crow twice, for there was a first and second cock crowing, the one at midnight, and the other near break of day.
Thou shalt deny me thrice; as he did.

bhtAttempts.bht: In this verse, there is a sense of urgency and emphasis as the night progresses. The cock crowing twice serves as a significant marker, representing the passing of time before a denial would occur. The first-tier commentaries note the significance of the second crowing, emphasizing that the denial would take place well before the night is over. The prediction becomes more specific, focusing on the individual being addressed, reinforcing a sense of confident assurance in the words spoken. The third-tier commentary provides further context, explaining that the first and second crowing of the cock occur at midnight and near dawn, respectively, indicating that the denial would occur three times, just as the individual did.

In the unfolding events of that night, there is a climactic moment when the cock crows twice. This signifies the passing of time and symbolizes the impending denial to come. The denial will not only happen on that day but specifically during this night, before it is even over. The emphasis on the second crowing of the cock brings clarity to the timeline, noting that the denial will occur long before the break of dawn.

In this critical moment, the cock's dual crowing holds significance, marking the passage of time. The convergence of this day and night amplifies the weight of what is to come. The compound verb, deny, denotes a complete rejection. It is noteworthy that the first cockcrow acts as a signal, inviting subsequent crowing. Remarkably, the Fayum papyrus aligns with Mark, affirming the twofold crowing. By acknowledging the cock-crowing as a marker of the third watch, the specific timeline of events is further illuminated.

Notably, the first crowing serves as a signal for further crows, while the Fayum papyrus supports the idea of a repetition. Delving deeper, the mention of the cock-crowing and its association with the third watch provides valuable context for understanding the timeline in question.
